trans-unit.source: Using soft delete in Mobile Services (Windows Store) | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Using soft delete in Mobile Services (Windows Store) | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services soft delete feature in your application
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure Mobile Services soft delete feature in your application

trans-unit.source: Tables created with either the JavaScript or .NET backend can optionally have soft delete enabled.
trans-unit.target: Tables created with either the JavaScript or .NET backend can optionally have soft delete enabled.

trans-unit.source: When using soft delete, a new column called \__deleted of [SQL bit type] is added to the database.
trans-unit.target: When using soft delete, a new column called \__deleted of [SQL bit type] is added to the database.

trans-unit.source: With soft delete enabled, a delete operation does not physically delete rows from the database, but rather sets the value of the deleted column to TRUE.
trans-unit.target: With soft delete enabled, a delete operation does not physically delete rows from the database, but rather sets the value of the deleted column to TRUE.

trans-unit.source: When querying records on a table with soft delete enabled, deleted rows are not returned in the query by default.
trans-unit.target: When querying records on a table with soft delete enabled, deleted rows are not returned in the query by default.

trans-unit.source: In order to request these rows, you must pass a query parameter \__includeDeleted=true in your REST Query operaation.
trans-unit.target: In order to request these rows, you must pass a query parameter \__includeDeleted=true in your REST Query operaation.

trans-unit.source: In the .NET client SDK, you can also use the helper method IMobileServiceTable.IncludeDeleted().
trans-unit.target: In the .NET client SDK, you can also use the helper method IMobileServiceTable.IncludeDeleted().

trans-unit.source: Soft delete support for the .NET backend first released with version 1.0.402 of the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend.
trans-unit.target: Soft delete support for the .NET backend first released with version 1.0.402 of the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend.

trans-unit.source: The latest NuGet packages are available here, <linkText>Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The latest NuGet packages are available here, <linkText>Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Some of the potential benefits of using soft delete:
trans-unit.target: Some of the potential benefits of using soft delete:

trans-unit.source: When using the [Offline data Sync for Mobile Services] feature, the client SDK automatically queries for deleted records and removes them from the local database.
trans-unit.target: When using the [Offline data Sync for Mobile Services] feature, the client SDK automatically queries for deleted records and removes them from the local database.

trans-unit.source: Without soft delete enabled, you need to write additional code on the backend so that the client SDK knows which records to remove from the local store.
trans-unit.target: Without soft delete enabled, you need to write additional code on the backend so that the client SDK knows which records to remove from the local store.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, the client local store and backend will be inconsistent with regard to these deleted records and the client method PurgeAsync() must be called to clear the local store.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, the client local store and backend will be inconsistent with regard to these deleted records and the client method PurgeAsync() must be called to clear the local store.

trans-unit.source: Some applications have a business requirement to never physically delete data, or to delete data only after it has been audited.
trans-unit.target: Some applications have a business requirement to never physically delete data, or to delete data only after it has been audited.

trans-unit.source: The soft delete feature can be useful in this scenario.
trans-unit.target: The soft delete feature can be useful in this scenario.

trans-unit.source: Soft delete can be used to implement an "undelete" feature, so that data deleted by accident can be recovered.
trans-unit.target: Soft delete can be used to implement an "undelete" feature, so that data deleted by accident can be recovered.

trans-unit.source: However, soft deleted records take up space in the database, so you should consider creating a scheduled job to periodically hard delete the soft deleted records.
trans-unit.target: However, soft deleted records take up space in the database, so you should consider creating a scheduled job to periodically hard delete the soft deleted records.

trans-unit.source: For an example of this, see [Using soft delete with the .NET backend] and [Using soft delete with the JavaScript backend].
trans-unit.target: For an example of this, see [Using soft delete with the .NET backend] and [Using soft delete with the JavaScript backend].

trans-unit.source: Your client code should also periodically call PurgeAsync() so that these hard deleted records do not remain in the device's local data store.
trans-unit.target: Your client code should also periodically call PurgeAsync() so that these hard deleted records do not remain in the device's local data store.

trans-unit.source: Soft delete support for the .NET backend first released with version 1.0.402 of the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend.
trans-unit.target: Soft delete support for the .NET backend first released with version 1.0.402 of the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend.

trans-unit.source: The latest NuGet packages are available here, <linkText>Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The latest NuGet packages are available here, <linkText>Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The following steps guide you on how to enable soft delete for a .NET backend mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The following steps guide you on how to enable soft delete for a .NET backend mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Open your .NET backend mobile service project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open your .NET backend mobile service project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: Right click the .NET backend project and click Manage NuGet Packages.
trans-unit.target: Right click the .NET backend project and click Manage NuGet Packages.

trans-unit.source: In the package manager dialog, click Nuget.org under updates and install version 1.0.402 or later of the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: In the package manager dialog, click Nuget.org under updates and install version 1.0.402 or later of the Microsoft Azure Mobile Services .NET Backend NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, expand the Controllers node under your .NET backend project and open your controller source for.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer for Visual Studio, expand the Controllers node under your .NET backend project and open your controller source for.

trans-unit.source: For example, TodoItemController.cs.
trans-unit.target: For example, TodoItemController.cs.

trans-unit.source: In the Initialize() method of your controller, pass the enableSoftDelete: true parameter to the EntityDomainManager constructor.
trans-unit.target: In the Initialize() method of your controller, pass the enableSoftDelete: true parameter to the EntityDomainManager constructor.

trans-unit.source: If you are creating a new table for your mobile service, you can enable soft delete on the table creation page.
trans-unit.target: If you are creating a new table for your mobile service, you can enable soft delete on the table creation page.

trans-unit.source: To enable soft delete on an existing table in the JavaScript backend:
trans-unit.target: To enable soft delete on an existing table in the JavaScript backend:

trans-unit.source: In the [Management Portal], click your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In the [Management Portal], click your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Then click the Data tab.
trans-unit.target: Then click the Data tab.

trans-unit.source: On the data page, click to select the desired table.
trans-unit.target: On the data page, click to select the desired table.

trans-unit.source: Then click the Enable Soft Delete button in the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Then click the Enable Soft Delete button in the command bar.

trans-unit.source: If the table already has soft delete enabled, this button will not appear but you will be able to see the \__deleted column when clicking the Browse or Columns tab for the table.
trans-unit.target: If the table already has soft delete enabled, this button will not appear but you will be able to see the \__deleted column when clicking the Browse or Columns tab for the table.

trans-unit.source: To disable soft delete for your table, click the Columns tab and then click the \__deleted column and the Delete button.
trans-unit.target: To disable soft delete for your table, click the Columns tab and then click the \__deleted column and the Delete button.

trans-unit.source: The following scheduled job purges soft deleted records that are more than a month old:
trans-unit.target: The following scheduled job purges soft deleted records that are more than a month old:

trans-unit.source: To learn more about schedule jobs with .NET backend Mobile Services, see: <linkText>Schedule recurring jobs with JavaScript backend Mobile Services</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: To learn more about schedule jobs with .NET backend Mobile Services, see: <linkText>Schedule recurring jobs with JavaScript backend Mobile Services</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: You use table scripts to add logic around the soft delete feature with JavaScript backend mobile services.
trans-unit.target: You use table scripts to add logic around the soft delete feature with JavaScript backend mobile services.

trans-unit.source: To detect an undelete request, use the property "undelete" in your update table script:
trans-unit.target: To detect an undelete request, use the property "undelete" in your update table script:

trans-unit.source: To retrieve deleted records via an HTTP request, add the query parameter "__includedeleted=true":
trans-unit.target: To retrieve deleted records via an HTTP request, add the query parameter "__includedeleted=true":

trans-unit.source: This is a sample scheduled job that deletes records that were updated prior to a particular date:
trans-unit.target: This is a sample scheduled job that deletes records that were updated prior to a particular date:

trans-unit.source: To learn more about scheduled jobs with JavaScript backend Mobile Services, see: <linkText>Schedule recurring jobs with JavaScript backend Mobile Services</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about scheduled jobs with JavaScript backend Mobile Services, see: <linkText>Schedule recurring jobs with JavaScript backend Mobile Services</linkText><title></title>.
